Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation

Source: R/validate_mimicsurv.R
validate_mimicsurv.Rd

This function conducts a comprehensive simulation study to validate the performance of hazard estimation methods using the person-years approach implemented in the mimicsurv package.

Usage

validate_mimicsurv(
  true_time_points,
  true_hazard_rates,
  sample_sizes = c(100, 200, 500),
  n_simulations = 100,
  max_followup = NULL,
  censoring_prob = 0.1,
  use_pweall = FALSE
)

Arguments

true_time_points

Time points defining intervals for simulation

true_hazard_rates

True hazard rates for each interval

sample_sizes

Vector of sample sizes to test (default: c(100, 200, 500))

n_simulations

Number of simulation replications (default: 100)

max_followup

Maximum follow-up time (default: max of time_points)

censoring_prob

Probability of random censoring (default: 0.1)

use_pweall

Logical, whether to use PWEALL package if available (default: FALSE)

Value

List containing:

simulation_parameters

Input parameters and true values

detailed_results

Detailed results for each sample size

summary_statistics

Summary statistics across all sample sizes

Details

The function performs the following steps for each sample size:

  1. Generate simulated data from piecewise exponential distribution

  2. Create Kaplan-Meier style summary tables

  3. Apply hazard estimation method

  4. Calculate bias, MSE, and coverage statistics

  5. Summarize performance across replications

Performance metrics include:

  • Bias: Mean difference between estimated and true values

  • MSE: Mean squared error

  • Coverage: Proportion of estimates within acceptable range

  • Convergence rate: Proportion of successful estimations

Examples

# Small simulation study
true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24)
true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)

validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(
  true_time_points = true_times,
  true_hazard_rates = true_hazards,
  sample_sizes = c(100, 200),
  n_simulations = 50,
  censoring_prob = 0.15
)
#> Running simulations for sample size 100...
#> Running simulations for sample size 200...

# View summary statistics
print(validation_result$summary_statistics)
#>       sample_size convergence_rate median_bias median_mse
#> n_100         100                1   0.1380898  1.4420564
#> n_200         200                1   0.1884929  0.5600045
